[[1978]]) | relatives = | website = }} '''Lesley Lawson''' nÃ©e '''Hornby''' (born 19 September 1949) known as ''' Twiggy''' is an [[English people|English]] [[model (person)|model]], actress, and singer. In the early-1960s she became a prominent British teenage model of [[swinging sixties]] London with others such as [[Penelope Tree]]. Twiggy was initially known for her [[androgynous]] looks, large eyes, long eyelashes, thin build, and short hair.{{cite news|title=Twiggy's wrinkles|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2005/nov/02/mainsection.commentanddebate2|date=2 November 2005|author=Roberts, Yvonne|work=The Guardian | location=London}} In 1966, she was named âThe Face of 1966â by the ''[[Daily Express]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/biography.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1949-09-19 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} and voted British Woman of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/twiggy.html |title=Twiggy - Biography on Bio |publisher=Thebiographychannel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} By 1967, Twiggy had modelled in France, Japan, and the U.S., and landed on the covers of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' and ''[[Tatler|The Tatler]]''. Her fame had spread worldwide. After modelling, Twiggy went on to enjoy a successful career as a screen, stage, and television actress. She has hosted her own series, ''Twiggy's People'', in which she interviewed celebrities, and also appeared as a judge on the reality show ''[[America's Next Top Model]]''. Her 1998 autobiography, ''Twiggy in Black and White'', entered the bestseller lists. Since 2005, she has modelled for [[Marks and Spencer]], most recently to promote their recent rebranding, appearing in TV adverts and print media, alongside [[Myleene Klass]], [[Erin O'Connor]], [[Lily Cole]] and others.{{cite news|author=Jane Gordon |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1054306/Exclusive-Twiggy-interview-Being-grown-woman-doesnt-mean-look-beautiful-individual-different.html#ixzz0c7bnvjO7 |title=Exclusive Twiggy interview: 'Being a grown-up woman doesn't mean you can't look beautiful, individual and different' |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2008-09-14 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} ==Early life== Twiggy was brought up in the northwest [[London]] suburb of [[Neasden]], the daughter of Helen "Nellie" Lydia Hornby (''nÃ©e'' Reeman), a factory worker for a printing firm, and William Norman Hornby, a master carpenter and joiner.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationsmemorybank.com/editorial/fashion_article_3.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=Nations Memory Bank |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Twiggyâs mother taught her to sew from an early age, and she used this skill to make her own clothing.{{cite web|url=http://www.inoutstar.com/news/Lesley-Hornby-aka-Twiggy-672.html |title=Lesley Hornby aka Twiggy Biography |publisher=Inout Star |date=2007-06-30 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} She attended the [[Queens Park Community School|Brondesbury and Kilburn High School]] in Salusbury Road, [[Kilburn, London|Kilburn]]. Twiggy is the youngest of three sisters. Shirley is 15 years older; Vivien is seven years older. == Personal life == Twiggy married American actor [[Michael Witney]] in 1977. They had a daughter, Carly, born in 1978. The marriage ended with his sudden death in 1983 from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. Twiggy met [[Leigh Lawson]] in 1984. In 1988 they worked on the film ''[[Madame Sousatzka]]'', and married that year in [[Sag Harbor]], [[Long Island]]. Lawson adopted Twiggyâs daughter, Carly, who took on his surname. The couple resides in London,{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1066965/Now-time-MY-swinging-sixties-How-getting-older-given-supermodel-Twiggy-new-lease-life.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Richard | last=Barber | title=Now it's time for MY swinging sixties! How getting older has given the very first supermodel Twiggy a new lease of life | date=2008-10-03}} and also own a home in Southwold, Suffolk.http://www.suffolktouristguide.com/Famous-Suffolk-People.asp In her official site, she describes herself as being an ardent supporter of [[breast cancer]] research, [[animal welfare]], and [[anti-fur]] campaigns. ==Modeling career (1965-1970)== [[File:Twiggy promo.jpg|thumb|
Twiggy in 1967, at the height of her modelling career, showing the look that made her famous.
]] ===1965â1967=== Twiggy is best remembered as one of the first international [[supermodel]]s and a fashion icon of the 1960s.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/breakfast/4725427.stm |title=The face of '66 |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-07-29 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Her greatest influence is [[Jean Shrimpton]],{{cite web|author=AAP |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/138961 |title=60s icon Twiggy offers fashion advice |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}{{cite web|url=http://channels.isp.netscape.com/celebrity/hollywoodexclusive.jsp?feature=ce_hol_09212005 |title=Dickinson 1st Supermodel? Not! Says Twiggy |publisher=Channels.isp.netscape.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} whom Twiggy considers to be the world's first supermodel. Twiggy has also been described as the successor to Jean Shrimpton.[http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-articles/famous-models-0409 Best Models of All Time: #7 Twiggy] ''Harper's Bazaar''.{{cite journal|title=TV: Camera on Twiggy; Cinema Verite Technique Helps Exploit Visit of Model Most in Vogue|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16F63C5C107B93CAAB178FD85F438685F9|work=The New York Times|author=Gould, Jack|date=1967-04-28}}{{cite journal|title=The Arrival of Twiggy|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=b1YEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA33&dq=successor+twiggy+shrimpton&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q|work=Life|date=1967-02-03}}{{cite journal|title=Pin Thin, Leggy Twiggy Is Tops|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19661124&id=sOAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2CcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7231,1716337|date=1966-11-24|work=Milwaukee Journal}} In January 1966, young Lesley Hornby had her hair colored and cut short in Mayfair at The House of Leonard,{{cite web|author=sentimentalsusan |url=http://modsixties.5forum.net/susan-camp-editors-updates-f9/twiggy-leonard-of-london-hairdo-magazine-1967-t544.htm |title=Twiggy & Leonard of London ~ HairDo Magazine 1967 |publisher=Modsixties.5forum.net |date=2008-11-10 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} owned by celebrity hairdresser Leonard.{{cite web|url=http://www.twiggylawson.co.uk/fashion.html |title=Twiggy - The Official Site |publisher=Twiggylawson.co.uk |date=1966-02-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} The hair stylist was looking for models on whom to try out his new crop haircut and he styled her hair in preparation for a few test head shots.{{cite news|author=Jess Cartner-Morley |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/sep/19/twiggy-at-60-interview |title=Twiggy at 60: 'It's amazing I didn't go bonkers' |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2009-09-19|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} A professional photographer Barry Lategan took several photos for Leonard, which the hairdresser hung in his salon. Deidre McSharry, a fashion journalist from the ''[[Daily Express]]'', saw the images and asked to meet the young girl.{{cite web|url=http://blog.fidmmuseum.org/museum/2009/11/twiggy-.html |title=Twiggy |publisher=FIDM Museum Blog|date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} McSharry arranged to have more photos taken. A few weeks later the publication featured an article and images of Hornby, declaring her âThe Face of â66.â{{cite news|author=Maev Kennedy |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/jul/08/twiggy-exhibition-national-portrait-gallery |title=Face of 2009: Gallery celebrates Twiggy's career |publisher=Guardian |date= 2009-07-08|accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} In it, the copy read: "The Cockney Kid with a face to launch a thousand shapes ... and she's only 16! - ''The Daily Express'', 23 February 1966. Hornby's career quickly took off. She was 5'6" tall (short for a model), weighed 8 [[stone (Imperial mass)|stone]] (51 kg, 110 lbs) and had a 31-23-32 figure, "with a new kind of streamlined, androgynous sex appeal."{{cite news|author= Cheever, Susan|date= May 1983|url= http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html|title= Twiggy|publisher= New York Times|accessdate= 2007-04-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109120757/http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html |archivedate = 2006-11-09}} Her hairdresser boyfriend, Nigel Davies, became her manager, changed his name to [[Justin de Villeneuve]], and persuaded her to change her name to Twiggy (from âTwigsâ, her childhood nickname{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}). De Villeneuve credits himself for Twiggyâs discovery and her modelling success, and his version of events is often quoted in other biographies.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/theguardian/2006/aug/01/features11.g2 |title=Summer of hate |publisher=The Guardian |date=2006-08-01 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London | first=Emine | last=Saner}} Ten years her senior, he managed her lucrative career for seven years, overseeing her finances and enterprises during her heyday as a model. Twiggy was soon seen in all the leading fashion magazines, commanding fees of [[Pound sterling|Â£]]80 an hour, bringing out her own line of clothes called âTwiggy Dressesâ in 1967,{{cite web|author=Clint Hough |url=http://www.sixtiescity.com/Fashion/Fashion.shtm |title=Bringing on back the good times |publisher=Sixties City |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} and taking the fashion world by storm.{{cite news|last=Bergin |first=Olivia |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/fashionnews/5972626/Twiggy-A-supermodels-life-in-photographs.html |title=Twiggy: A supermodelâs life in photographs |publisher=Telegraph |date=2009-08-04 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} âI hated what I looked like,â she said once, âso I thought everyone had gone stark raving mad.â Twiggyâs look centered on three qualities: her stick thin figure, a boyishly short haircut and strikingly dark eyelashes.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/ilove/years/1965/fashion2.shtml |title=Cult - I Love Twiggy in False Eyelashes |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Describing how she obtained her prominent eyelashes, now known as Twiggys, she said, âBack then I was layering three pairs of false eyelashes over my own and would paint extra âtwigsâ on my skin underneath.â{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1056252/Twiggys-beauty-secrets-eyes-lips.html#ixzz0c8KzYAkn |title=Twiggy's beauty secrets: eyes and lips |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2008-09-20 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} One month after the ''Daily Express'' article, Twiggy posed for her first shoot for ''Vogue''. A year later, she had appeared in 13 separate fashion shoots in international ''Vogue'' editions. ===1967â1970=== Twiggy arrived in [[New York]] in March 1967 at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK airport]], an event covered by the press.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hl-8Pej7bHo&feature=related |title=Twiggy Press Conference |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported on the Twiggy "phenomenon" in 1967, with the ''New Yorker'' devoting nearly 100 pages to the subject." That year she became an international sensation, modelling in France, Japan, and America, and landing the cover of Paris ''Vogue'' in May,{{cite web|url=http://hauteworld.blogspot.com/2009/10/vogue-covers-1920-2009-paris-france.html |title=Vogue Covers 1920-2009 (Paris, France)|publisher=Hauteworld.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} the cover of US ''Vogue'' three times, in April, July and November, and the cover of British ''Vogue'' in October. In 1967, an editorial on p. 63 of the March 15 edition of ''Vogue'' described her as an "extravaganza that makes the look of the sixties." The [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]'s 2009 catalogue of ''Style: Model as Muse Embodying Fashion'' stated that
Twiggy's adolescent physique was the perfect frame for the androgynous styles that began to emerge in the 1960s. The trend was manifested in a number of templates: sweet A-line dresses with collars and neckties, suits and dresses that took their details from military uniforms, or, in the case of [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], and explicit transposition of the male tuxedo to women. Simultaneously, under the rubric of 'unisex,' designs that were minimalistic, including Nehru suits and space-agey jumpsuits, were proposed by designers such as [[Pierre Cardin]] and [[Andre Courreges]], and, most famously in the U.S.A., by [[Rudi Gernreich]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/modelmuse.html |title=Style: Model as Muse at the Metropolitan Museum of Art |publisher=Thecityreview.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}
Twiggy has been photographed by such noted photographers as [[Cecil Beaton]], [[Richard Avedon]], [[Melvin Sokolsky]], Ronald Traeger, [[Bert Stern]], [[Norman Parkinson]], [[Annie Leibovitz]] and [[Steven Meisel]]. ===Reaction=== Twiggy and the magazines featuring her image polarised critics from the start. Her boyishly thin image was criticized as, and is still blamed for, promoting an "unhealthy" body ideal for women.{{cite journal|url=http://ap.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/full/30/3/257 |title=Body Image, Media, and Eating Disorders |author = Derenne and Beresin |volume = 30 |number = 3 |page = 257 |journal = Acad Psychiatry |doi=10.1176/appi.ap.30.3.257 |publisher=Ap.psychiatryonline.org |date=2006-01-30 |accessdate=2010-05-01}}{{cite web|url = http://www.times.com/specials/magazine4/articles/twiggy.html|title = Stick Thin|author = Susan Cheever}}{{Dead link|date=June 2011}} "Twiggy came along at a time when teen-age spending power was never greater," said Su Dalgleish, fashion correspondent for the London Daily Mail. "With that underdeveloped, boyish figure, she is an idol to the 14- and 15-year-old kids. She makes virtue of all the terrible things of [[gawky]], miserable, adolescence."{{cite web|author=sentimentalsusan |url=http://modsixties.5forum.net/susan-camp-editors-updates-f9/new-twiggy-1967-newsweek-cover-article-t476.htm |title=NEW Twiggy 1967 Newsweek Cover & Article |publisher=Modsixties.5forum.net |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}} At the height of her fame, Mark Cohen, president of Leeds women's shop had an even harsher view: "Her legs remind me of two painted worms." Yet Twiggy had her supporters. [[Diana Vreeland]] of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' stated, "She's no flash in the pan. She is the mini-girl in the mini-era. She's delicious looking." In recent years Twiggy has spoken out against the trend of waif-thin models, explaining that her own thin weight as a teenager was natural: ""I was very skinny, but that was just my natural build. I always ate sensibly â being thin was in my genes."{{cite web|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/america-next-top-model-judge-twiggy-too-thin-models-terrifying-1010539.php |title='America's Next Top Model' judge Twiggy: Too thin models "terrifying"|publisher=Reality TV World |date=2006-11-19 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} On 10 December 1969, despite being 20 years old, she was selected as the special guest for one of the first editions of the UK television series [[This_Is_Your_Life_(UK_TV_series)|This Is Your Life]].[http://www.eofftv.com/t/thi/this_is_your_life_1969_main.htm] ==Stage, film, television and singing career== ===1970â1979=== After four years of modelling, Twiggy retired in 1970, claiming "You can't be a clothes hanger for your entire life!" {{cite news |first=Anna |last=Slater |title=Twiggy at 60; The super-skinny model who found fame in the Sixties has finally come of age. Anna Slater lists the triumphs, the tragedies and the trivia |work=Independent on Sunday |page=48 |date=September 13, 2009 |accessdate=2 January 2010}} She broke off with Justin de Villeneuve, who had been overseeing her business affairs since 1966, and released him from his duties as her manager, claiming in later years that "her career had more to do with that famous picture of her with those funny painted eyelashes, which appeared in the ''Daily Express'' under the headline 'The Face of 66' " than with his promotional efforts. Twiggy embarked on an award-winning acting and singing career, starring in a variety of roles on stage and screen, and recording albums. In 1971, she made her film debut as an extra in [[Ken Russell]]'s ''[[The Devils (film)|The Devils]]''. The same year, she performed her first leading role in features as Polly Browne in Ken Russell's adaptation of [[Sandy Wilson]]'s pastiche of 1920s hit musicals ''[[The Boy Friend]]''. This marked her initial collaboration with [[Tommy Tune]], and won her two [[30th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards in 1972]] ([[Golden Globe Award for New Star of the Year â Actress|New Star of the Year - Actress]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress â Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress in a Musical or Comedy]]). In 1974, she made her [[West End theatre|West End]] stage debut in ''[[Cinderella]]'', and made a second feature, the thriller ''[[W (1974 film)|W]]''; co-starred with future husband Michael Whitney, and hosted her own British television series, ''Twiggs'' (later renamed ''Twiggy''). In October 1975, she sang at the live performance of [[Roger Glover]]'s [[The Butterfly Ball and the Grasshopper's Feast]] album at the [[Royal Albert Hall]]. The concert was filmed and produced by [[Tony Klinger]] and released to theaters in 1976. In November, 1976 she made an appearance on ''[[The Muppet Show]],'' in which she sang "In My Life," a Beatles song.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q407R9QskPU&feature=related |title=The Muppet Show Season 1 Episode 21 Part 1 |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-05-01}}{{cite web|url=http://muppet.wikia.com/wiki/Episode_121:_Twiggy |title=Episode 121: Twiggy|publisher=Muppet.wikia.com |date=2010-01-01 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} In 1976, Twiggy signed to Mercury records and released the albums ''Twiggy'' and ''Please Get My Name Right'', discs that contained both pop and country tunes. ''Twiggy'' sold very well, peaking on the UK charts at no.33, and gave Twiggy a silver disc for good sales. The album contains Twiggy's top twenty hit single, "Here I Go Again". "Please Get My Name Right" made it to no.35 in 1977.A single A Woman In Love,failed to chart for Twiggy in 1977 but was a hit for the Three Degrees in 1978. In 1978, the television distribution arm of [[American International Pictures]], in an effort to gain additional syndication value in the U.S. to the [[London Weekend Television|LWT]] rock music series ''[[Supersonic (TV series)|Supersonic]]'', repackaged the musical performances with Twiggy replacing [[Mike Mansfield Productions|Mike Mansfield]]'s introductions. The new series was titled ''[[Twiggy's Jukebox]]'', and ran in most of the major television markets in the U.S. during the 1978-1978 TV season. Coincidentally, Twiggy herself had performed "Here I Go Again" and "Vanilla Ole" on ''Supersonic'' in September 1976, and these performances were included in the refurbished program. After the initial season, Twiggy left the series, and American International Television continued ''[[Twiggy's Jukebox|Jukebox]]'' with [[Britt Ekland]] as host, using standard [[music videos]] rather than clips from ''Supersonic''. ===1980â1999=== In 1980 Twiggy made a cameo appearance in ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]''. She starred as Eliza Doolittle in 1981 opposite Robert Powell in the Yorkshire TV production of ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' and in 1983, she made her Broadway debut in the musical, ''[[My One and Only]]'', starring and co-staged by Tommy Tune, for which she earned a [[Tony Award|Tony]] nomination. In 1986 She played opposite [[Robin Williams]] In the comedy ''[[Club Paradise]]''. In 1987, she played a vaudeville performer in the British television special ''[[The Little Match Girl]]'' and in 1988, she appeared in a supporting role in ''[[Madame Sousatzka]]'' opposite second husband Leigh Lawson. In 1989, she was cast as Hannah Chaplin, mother to Charles, in the British television movie ''Young Charlie Chaplin''; aired in the United States on PBS' ''[[WonderWorks]]''. In 1991, she co-starred in her first American network dramatic television series, the short-lived CBS sitcom ''[[Princesses]]''. Of eight episodes completed, only five aired. In 1997, Twiggy acted in the Chichester Festival Theatre revival of [[Noel Coward]]'s ''[[Blithe Spirit (play)|Blithe Spirit]]''. A year later, she played Gertrude Lawrence in the biographical stage revue ''[[Noel Coward|Noel]] and Gertie'' at Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, Long Island. In 1999, she returned to the New York stage in an off-Broadway production ''If Love Were All'', a revised version of ''Noel and Gertie'', written and directed by Leigh Lawson; what set this edition apart were its tap numbers in period style. She starred as Gertrude Lawrence opposite Harry Groener's Noel Coward. ===2000â2009=== In 2001, Twiggy co-hosted the British magazine programme ''[[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]''. In 2003, she released another album, ''Midnight Blue''. Seventeen of the CD's 20 tracks had previously unreleased material from 1982â1990, including a duet with Leo Sayer, 'Save The Last Dance For Me' & a cover of the Stones' 'Ruby Tuesday'. ''Feel Emotion'' and ''Diamond'' have both been released onto CD format since. In 2005, she joined the cast of the television show ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' for Cycles 5-9 as one of four judges, and a year later, she appeared on the cover of the Icons issue of ''SWINDLE'' magazine. She also returned to modelling, fronting a major television, press and billboard campaign for [[Marks & Spencer]], the British department store chain. Her involvement in the advertising campaign has been credited for reviving Marks and Spencer's fortunes.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/twiggy-this-years-model-again-510583.html |title=Twiggy: This year's model. Again - This Britain, UK |publisher=The Independent |date=2005-10-12 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | location=London}} In 2006, she portrayed herself as a nineteen-year-old in the radio play ''Elevenses with Twiggy'' for BBC Radio 4's ''[[The Afternoon Play (BBC)|Afternoon Play]]'' series. She did not return to ''America's Next Top Model'' in its tenth season due to scheduling conflicts.{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/dailydish/detail?blogid=7&entry_id=22273 |title=Twiggy Quits 'America's Next Top Model' |publisher=SFGate |date=2007-11-27 |accessdate=2010-05-01 | first=Karen | last=Reardanz}} Her replacement was model [[Paulina Porizkova]].{{cite web|author=Zap2It.com |url=http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-paulinaporizkovatwiggyantm,0,4534084.story?coll=zap-news-headlines |title=Twiggy Replaced on 'America's Next Top Model' |publisher=Zap2it |date=2007-11-26 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Also in 2007, Sepia Records released a previously shelved album that Twiggy recorded in 1979, produced by Donna Summer and Juergen Koppers. ''Heaven In My Eyes ["Discotheque"]'' contains the eight original tracks due to be released, plus four remixes by [[The Outsider]]{{Disambiguation needed|date=June 2011}}. The album was also made available on iTunes. She is signed to London agency [[Models 1]]. In 2008, she supported the ''[http://www.targetbreastcancer.org.uk Fashion Targets Breast Cancer]'' campaign in support of [[Breakthrough Breast Cancer]], alongside fellow celebrities â comedian [[Alan Carr]], singer [[Natalie Imbruglia]], actress [[Anna Friel]] and DJ & presenter [[Edith Bowman]]. In the summer of 2009, beauty company Olay debuted its "Definity Eye Cream" campaign depicting Twiggy. Accusations of airbrushing created a stir with the media and public. A website campaign set up by Jo Swinson, the Scottish Liberal Democrat MP, attracted 700 individual complaints.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8415176.stm |title=Airbrushed Twiggy photo 'misleading' |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2010-05-01}} [[Procter & Gamble]] admitted to minor retouching and replaced the image. The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) announced that the ad gave a âmisleadingâ impression, but that no further action was required because the image had already been withdrawn. Its announcement said:
However, we considered that the post-production re-touching of this ad, specifically in the eye area, could give consumers a misleading impression of the effect the product could achieve. We considered that the combination of references to "younger looking eyes", including the claim "reduces the look of wrinkles and dark circles for brighter, younger looking eyes", and post-production re-touching of Twiggyâs image around the eye area, was likely to mislead.
==2010 to present== Twiggy remains in the forefront of fashion for women of her age.
